key_facts: LinkedIn Series B pitch presented three business ideas with no revenue at the time
The three business ideas were not the source of LinkedIn's majority revenue
Individual subscription was initially believed to be the primary revenue model
Corporate product inquiries began two weeks after launching the individual subscription model
A paper mock-up of the corporate product was created despite not being actively developed
A salesperson was hired to test interest in the corporate product
Twenty out of thirty contacted companies expressed interest in purchasing the corporate product
The company pivoted to focus on building the corporate product as the main revenue driver
The corporate product became the majority of LinkedIn's revenue and remains so today
key_opinions: Presenting three options during the pitch reflected uncertainty about the correct path
The rapid corporate interest was unexpected and accelerated development timelines
The pivot to the corporate product was a strategic necessity based on market feedback
The initial belief in individual subscriptions was incorrect given actual user behavior
The corporate product's success demonstrates the importance of listening to customer demand
key_datapoints: Two weeks after launching individual subscription, corporate inquiries began
20 out of 30 contacted companies showed interest in the corporate product
Corporate product became the majority of LinkedIn's revenue
Initial revenue model assumed to be individual subscription
Pivot occurred after receiving early corporate interest
